metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript HTML DOM Elements (Nodes)
Adding and Removing Nodes (HTML Elements)
content.html: Adding and Removing Nodes (HTML Elements)

content.text: Creating New HTML Elements (Nodes)
To add a new element to the HTML DOM, you must create the element (element node) first, and then append it to an existing element.
content.html: To add a new element to the HTML DOM, you must create the element (element node) first, and then append it to an existing element.

content.code:
This is a paragraph.

This is another paragraph.
content.code_html:
<div id="div1">
  <p id="p1">This is a paragraph.</p>
  <p id="p2">This is another paragraph.</p>
</div>

<script>
const para = document.createElement("p");
const node = document.createTextNode("This is new.");
para.appendChild(node);

const element = document.getElementById("div1");
element.appendChild(para);
</script>

content.text: Example Explained

This code creates a new

element:
content.html: This code creates a new <p> element:

content.code_html: const para = document.createElement("p");

content.text:
To add text to the

element, you must create a text node first. This code creates a text node:
content.html: To add text to the <p> element, you must create a text node first. This code creates a text node:

syntaxHighlighting.text: const node = document.createTextNode("This is a new paragraph.");

content.code: const node = document.createTextNode("This is a new paragraph.");

syntax_highlighting.text: const node = document.createTextNode("This is a new paragraph.");

content.code_html: const node = document.createTextNode("This is a new paragraph.");

syntax_highlighting_data.text: const node = document.createTextNode("This is a new paragraph.");

content.text:
Then you must append the text node to the

element:
content.html: Then you must append the text node to the <p> element:

content.code_html: para.appendChild(node);

content.text: Finally you must append the new element to an existing element.
content.html: Finally you must append the new element to an existing element.

content.text: This code finds an existing element:
content.html: This code finds an existing element:

content.code_html: const element = document.getElementById("div1");

content.text: This code appends the new element to the existing element:
content.html: This code appends the new element to the existing element:

content.code_html: element.appendChild(para);

content.text: Creating new HTML Elements - insertBefore()
The appendChild() method in the previous example, appended the new element as the last child of the parent.
content.html: The appendChild() method in the previous example, appended the new element as the last child of the parent.

content.text: If you don't want that you can use the insertBefore() method:
content.html: If you don't want that you can use the insertBefore() method:

content.code:
This is a paragraph.

This is another paragraph.
content.code_html:
<div id="div1">
  <p id="p1">This is a paragraph.</p>
  <p id="p2">This is another paragraph.</p>
</div>

<script>
const para = document.createElement("p");
const node = document.createTextNode("This is new.");
para.appendChild(node);

const element = document.getElementById("div1");
const child = document.getElementById("p1");
element.insertBefore(para, child);
</script>

content.text: Removing Existing HTML Elements
To remove an HTML element, use the remove() method:
content.html: To remove an HTML element, use the remove() method:

content.code:
This is a paragraph.

This is another paragraph.
content.code_html:
<div>
  <p id="p1">This is a paragraph.</p>
  <p id="p2">This is another paragraph.</p>
</div>

<script>
const elmnt = document.getElementById("p1"); elmnt.remove();
</script>

content.text: Example Explained

The HTML document contains a
element with two child nodes (two

elements):
content.html: The HTML document contains a <div> element with two child nodes (two <p> elements):

content.code_html:
<div>
  <p id="p1">This is a paragraph.</p>
  <p id="p2">This is another paragraph.</p>
</div>

content.text: Find the element you want to remove:
content.html: Find the element you want to remove:

content.code_html: const elmnt = document.getElementById("p1");

content.text: Then execute the remove() method on that element:
content.html: Then execute the remove() method on that element:

content.code_html: elmnt.remove();

content.text: The remove() method does not work in older browsers, see the example below on how to use removeChild() instead.
content.html: The remove() method does not work in older browsers, see the example below on how to use removeChild() instead.

content.text: Removing a Child Node
For browsers that does not support the remove() method, you have to find the parent node to remove an element:
content.html: For browsers that does not support the remove() method, you have to find the parent node to remove an element:

content.code:
This is a paragraph.

This is another paragraph.
content.code_html:
<div id="div1">
  <p id="p1">This is a paragraph.</p>
  <p id="p2">This is another paragraph.</p>
</div>

<script>
const parent = document.getElementById("div1");
const child = document.getElementById("p1");
parent.removeChild(child);
</script>

content.text: Example Explained

This HTML document contains a
element with two child nodes (two

elements):
content.html: This HTML document contains a <div> element with two child nodes (two <p> elements):

content.code_html:
<div id="div1">
  <p id="p1">This is a paragraph.</p>
  <p id="p2">This is another paragraph.</p>
</div>

content.text: Find the element with id="div1" :
content.html: Find the element with id="div1":

content.code_html: const parent = document.getElementById("div1");

content.text:
Find the

element with id="p1" :
content.html: Find the <p> element with id="p1":

content.code_html: const child = document.getElementById("p1");

content.text: Remove the child from the parent:
content.html: Remove the child from the parent:

content.code_html: parent.removeChild(child);

content.text: Here is a common workaround: Find the child you want to remove, and use its parentNode property to find the parent:
content.html: Here is a common workaround: Find the child you want to remove, and use its parentNode property to find the parent:

content.code_html:
const child = document.getElementById("p1");
child.parentNode.removeChild(child);

content.text: Replacing HTML Elements
To replace an element to the HTML DOM, use the replaceChild() method:
content.html: To replace an element to the HTML DOM, use the replaceChild() method:

content.code:
This is a paragraph.

This is another paragraph.
content.code_html:
<div id="div1">
  <p id="p1">This is a paragraph.</p>
  <p id="p2">This is another paragraph.</p>
</div>

<script>
const para = document.createElement("p");
const node = document.createTextNode("This is new.");
para.appendChild(node);

const parent = document.getElementById("div1");
const child = document.getElementById("p1");
parent.replaceChild(para, child);
</script>
